Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Molecular Rheology of Architecturally Complex Polymers

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1254340
Schroeder

Polymers underlie an untold number of technologies ranging from consumer products to electronics. Despite recent progress in the field, a full understanding of the flow properties of entangled polymer solutions is lacking. A major challenge in polymer processing arises from the unusually complex flow dynamics of branched polymers, wherein molecular topology ultimately determines macroscopic material response. Traditionally, bulk rheological methods have been used to study polymer flows, but these methods average away individual molecular motions. To overcome these challenges, a new molecular approach to probe dynamics is required.

Intellectual Merit. The proposed research aims to provide a molecular-level view of branched polymer dynamics in flow using single molecule methods. Polymer stress relaxation and the non-linear flow properties of entangled comb polymers will be studied, and single polymer data obtained from experiments will be compared to theoretical models. In this way, direct observation of backbone and branch relaxation at the molecular level will be pursued, facilitated by using dual-color fluorescent dyes on the backbone and side-chain branches. The proposed research relies on three innovative technologies developed in the PI's lab: (1) custom synthesis of linear and branched single stranded DNA (ssDNA) polymers with properties similar to synthetic chains, (2) dual-color labeling of branched ssDNA polymers at architecturally-specific locations such as backbones and branches, and (3) automated microfluidic-based flow systems that allow for controlled fluid flows, combined with single molecule imaging of polymer conformations with nanoscale resolution.

Broader Impacts. This research will provide a detailed molecular-level view of entangled topological networks, thereby establishing a direct link between the molecular properties of branched polymers and macroscopic flow properties (e.g., viscosity and stress). The proposed combined custom synthesis and molecular imaging approach will allow for the guided design of polymeric materials with tailored properties that give rise to a desired processing response. In this way, the proposed work will provide crucial insight into the improved processing and manufacturing of branched polymers. The proposed work also integrates cutting-edge research in molecular rheology with the educational training of graduate and undergraduate students, which is accomplished by mentoring students to work in a collaborative workspace. Educational outreach will be incorporated by working with the Illinois iRise program, which actively engages local K-12 high school science teachers in the Urbana-Champaign area to develop experimental labs for the classroom, and mentors middle and high school students from underrepresented groups, with a particular focus on sparking an interest in science through hands-on experiments. The proposed research also includes participation in the Multicultural Engineering Recruitment for Graduate Education (MERGE) program at the University of Illinois, which aims to recruit students from underrepresented groups in engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Polymeric materials underlie an untold number of technologies ranging from consumer products to electronics. Despite tremendous progress in the field, we still lack a full understanding of the flow properties of entangled polymer solutions. A major challenge in processing polymer solutions and melts arises from the unusually complex flow properties of branched polymers, wherein molecular topology (polymer chain branching) ultimately determines macroscopic material response. To overcome these challenges, we pursued a new molecular-based approach to probe the dynamics of single branched polymers using fluorescence microscopy and polymer synthesis. A major goal of this CAREER program was to provide the first single molecule study of branched polymer dynamics in flow using well characterized materials. On this project, we studied the dynamics of single branched polymers labeled with single-color and dual-color fluorescent dyes, which effectively enabled simultaneous analysis of different portions of the polymer chain (backbone and branch) at the molecular level for the first time. Traditionally, bulk rheological methods have been used to study polymer flows, but these methods average away individual molecular motions. In this way, our work effectively extended molecular-based techniques to the fields of rheology and complex fluids. The major outcomes of the work were severalfold. First, our research has provided a detailed molecular-level view of the relaxation and stretching dynamics of single comb-shaped polymers in flow. We directly measured the role of branch location and branch size on the relaxation and stretching dynamics of single comb polymers in flows commonly encountered in polymer processing. Further, we also directly measured the force-extension relation (or elasticity) of single comb polymers using single molecule techniques for the first time. These results will greatly aid in modeling and simulation of branched polymers in non-equilibrium flow. In related work, we directly observed the single molecule dynamics of chemically heterogeneous and thermoresponsive copolymers using our techniques, thereby directly revealing the effect of temperature on thermally responsive polymers at the molecular scale for the first time. Moreover, we are continuing to directly measure the dynamics of single branched polymers in non-dilute polymer solutions, where interchain interactions drastically change the behavior of the materials due to 'hooking' events and chain-chain entanglements. Through these efforts, our work has aided in establishing a direct link between the molecular properties of branched polymers and macroscopic flow properties (e.g. viscosity and stress). Our work will continue to provide crucial insight into the improved processing and manufacturing of branched polymers, with an eye toward the development of advanced manufacturing techniques based on advanced functional materials, which will be important in the 21st century world economy. In total, this award has produced 18 peer-reviewed publications in high-profile journals such as Physical Review Letters, Macromolecules, Journal of Rheology, ACS Macro Letters, and Proceedings of the National Academy of the Sciences, among others, all with NSF support acknowledged. Moreover, the award has supported the mentoring and training of at least 8 graduate students and undergraduate students and directly funded research in 4 Ph.D. theses.
